author: Joe Himelstein
title: Youbiquitor Dapp for gig workers
description: Apps like Uber, Doordash and others take advantage of independent contractors under the false promise that you can "be your own boss".

assessments.note: A free marketplace that's attractive to makers and takers alike would indeed drive adoption.

While it is a useful applicattion that will bring many new people onto the blockchain if correctly implemented, the costs are too high for such an application as compared to what other proposals do with a similar budget. It is failed to describe how this would be connected to blockchain.

I found this idea very interesting because it intends to make the relationship between companies, customers and workers more just. It is known that with the pandemic, small companies lost customers and many had to end their activities, while larger organizations grew, in a way, as the author cites in the text, exploratory and prejudicial to workers. When building an application in which companies can create personalized contracts, get in direct contact with customers, etc., as mentioned by the author, review various business practices, it may be possible to make the situation fairer for everyone. Regarding the impact of the project on the Cardano community, I found it a bit confusing where our group's activities would fit. It would be beneficial if the author clarified these issues better.

The problem description and solution make sense, are reasonable and are within the scope of the challenge.

The proposal describes the potential of the gig economy market and shows potential for positive impact for the challenge and for Cardano, however the lack of roadmap, metrics and goals makes it impossible to measure the potential impact of the proposal.
If the end user experience is outstanding, this proposal can drive adoption for Crypto and Cardano and benefit a lot of people at the same time.

The technological side of things is ignored in this proposal. An idea (even if it's good) means nothing if it cannot be implemented by the team. $50,000 is a big chunk of money but probably not enough over a six year effort that does not have developers or marketing experts.

There is not enough detail on the technical side of what would actually be built or evidence the proposer has the ability to deliver this. More detail should be provided on the marketing strategy as this is key to it being successful.
The proposer provided no verifiable credentials and has no team with the core competentcies to develop such a DApp assembled yet. There is no schedule/no milestones set, and no detailed budget given.

The author cites having many years of experience in relevant companies, in addition to having already worked with online marketing. However, he does not specify what these companies would be, he does not give examples of some of the work he has already done. The information about his professional trajectory is a little vague. In addition, he also does not say whether he intends to form a team to build the application, which professionals he would hire, with what functions and so on. Therefore, I think that in relation to the project's execution capacity, the information is insufficient.

The proposer described experiences  with marketing and sales and as an entrepreneur,, but did not indicate sources to support these claims. It is important that details about experience and qualification are made available, so that the community has easy and transparent access, a link to Linkedin can be an effective way to resolve this.

Considering that the idea of ​​the project is to create a dapp, it is important to include the number of developers required to create the application and the qualifications of each member of the team. (This was not described in the proposal)

The plan has a well-articulated rationale on the problem and ideas on the solution, but there is no concrete plan for implementation. There is no budget breakdown.

The issue of compliance with regulators and local governments was mentioned, but one of the problems with apps in the gig economy is that their dependence on government regulation creates a weakness related to taxes model, this can make the project's economic model unfeasible, as occurs with Uber in several locations. Jurisdictions where Uber is subject to regulations where there is a considerable increase in tax burdens often cause Uber to simply stop operating in these jurisdictions. In addition, regulation ends up creating a problem with labor ties that may force dapp's creator to bear the costs, which would imply a transfer of costs to users, compromising the supply and demand relationship and putting pressure on dapp's financial viability.. Without a sufficiently decentralized model, this type of project may not be feasible.

I recommend detailing the proposal with the mentioned points and elaborating a new proposal based on the Catalyst documentation.

You are doing great work here, but you need a great team to make this proposal succeed. The budget needs to be defined. Keep looking for team members with relevant experience and hopefully next fund your proposal will be in better shape and even more attractive.

The proposal does not break down the fund allocation. How is the proposer planing to attract talent that can implement the vague proposal? How does the proposal, if implemented, account for gig workers outbidding each other and thus worsen the problem that the proposal aims to solve? How do you onboard businesses that do not want to negotiate individual wages? It is also unclear how the proposer plans to be in compliance with regulations (something that is mentioned in the business plan). How much money is allocated for legal services?

The information provided is insufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.
Not feasible in current format. More detailed technical, marketing and economic plan should be provided.

While the creation of a MVP and the assembly of a team are milestones that could be measured, nothing else is contained in the proposal that could be considered an auditable milestone. The proposal overall fails to set a concrete plan of action. no diversified success criteria are defined.

The only part of the project that has a very detailed action plan is marketing. I believe that because of the author's training. In relation to this, it is very clear which paths to take and why. However, there is a lack of detail in relation to the rest of the project, how this application would be built, how long each step would take place and so on. Also, it would be beneficial to include an explanation of how the financing money would be used, nothing is mentioned about it, which, unfortunately, makes the execution of the project very abstract, not measurable.
There is no information to assess auditability. Include metrics, KPIs, roadmap, budget breakdown according to the Catalyst documentation.

The vision of what Youbiquitor wants to be is clear. When more team members are on board I'm sure there will be better defined metrics in place.
Launching the app in a new country every year seems doable, but more potential challenges/risks needs to be mentioned and addressed. You are already solving some problems, but what about new potential problems 
that might surface. Ex. The gig world involves a lot of people that still needs some crypto savvy. How will they acquire and hold ADA for your app?

solution: Youbiquitor allows contractors to customize their business profile, personalize fee structures and offer various types of services.
experience: Entrepreneur, co-founded non-profit at age 18. 6+ years online marketing and sales. 14+ years unique experience in relevant industries.
